standard_metadata.standard_description: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $3(x+5)=-4x+8$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}3(x+5)&=-4x+8\\\\ 3x+15&=-4x+8&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ 7x+15&=8 &(\text{Add } 4x \text{ to both sides})\\\\ 7x&=-7&(\text{Subtract } 15 \text{ from both sides}) \\\\ x&=-1 &(\text{Divide both sides by } 7) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $7(y+3)=5y+8$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}7(y+3)&=5y+8\\\\ 7y+21&=5y+8&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ 2y+21&=8 &(\text{Subtract } 5y \text{ from both sides})\\\\ 2y&=-13&(\text{Subtract } 21 \text{ from both sides}) \\\\ y&=-\dfrac{13}{2} &(\text{Divide both sides by } 2) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-5(z+1)=-2z+10$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $z=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-5(z+1)&=-2z+10\\\\ -5z-5&=-2z+10&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ -3z-5&=10 &(\text{Add } 2z \text{ to both sides})\\\\ -3z&=15&(\text{Add } 5 \text{ to both sides}) \\\\ z&=-5 &(\text{Divide both sides by } -3) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-6(x+7)=-4x-2$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-6(x+7)&=-4x-2\\\\ -6x-42&=-4x-2&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ -2x-42&=-2 &(\text{Add } 4x \text{ to both sides})\\\\ -2x&=40&(\text{Add } 42 \text{ to both sides}) \\\\ x&=-20 &(\text{Divide both sides by } -2) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $3(y+9)=12y+13$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}3(y+9)&=12y+13\\\\ 3y+27&=12y+13&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ -9y+27&=13 &(\text{Subtract } 12y \text{ from both sides})\\\\ -9y&=-14&(\text{Subtract } 27 \text{ from both sides}) \\\\ y&=\dfrac{14}{9} &(\text{Divide both sides by } -9) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $3z+9+14z=4z+5$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $z=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}3z+9+14z&=4z+5\\\\ 17z+9&=4z+5& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 13z+9&=5 &(\text{Subtract }  4z \text{ from both sides})\\\\ 13z&=-4&(\text{Subtract } 9 \text{  from both sides}) \\\\ z&=-\dfrac{4}{13} &(\text{Divide both  sides by } 13) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $5x+8-7x=-4x+1$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}5x+8-7x&=-4x+1\\\\ -2x+8&=-4x+1& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 2x+8&=1 &(\text{Add } 4x \text{ to both sides})\\\\ 2x&=-7&(\text{Subtract } 8 \text{  from both sides}) \\\\ x&=-\dfrac{7}{2} &(\text{Divide both  sides by } 2) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-6y+13+9y=8y-3$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-6y+13+9y&=8y-3\\\\ 3y+13&=8y-3& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ -5y+13&=-3 &(\text{Subtract }  8y \text{ from both sides})\\\\ -5y&=-16&(\text{Subtract } 13 \text{  from both sides}) \\\\ y&=\dfrac{16}{5} &(\text{Divide both  sides by } -5) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-2z+10+7z=16z+7$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $z=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-2z+10+7z&=16z+7\\\\ 5z+10&=16z+7& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ -11z+10&=7 &(\text{Subtract }  16z \text{ from both sides})\\\\ -11z&=-3&(\text{Subtract } 10 \text{  from both sides}) \\\\ z&=\dfrac{3}{11} &(\text{Divide both  sides by } -11) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $20z-5-12z=10z+8$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $z=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}20z-5-12z&=10z+8\\\\ 8z-5&=10z+8& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ -2z-5&=8 &(\text{Subtract }  10z \text{ from both sides})\\\\ -2z&=13&(\text{Add } 5 \text{  to both sides}) \\\\ z&=-\dfrac{13}{2} &(\text{Divide both  sides by } -2) \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has exactly one solution.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation  have ?**  $-3x+9-2x=-12-5x$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-3x+9-2x&=-12-5x\\\\ -5x+9&=-12-5x&(\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 9&=-12 &(\text{Add } 5x \text{ to both sides})\\\\ \end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-15y+7+17y=2y+70$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.     [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-15y+7+17y&=2y+70\\\\ 2y+7&=2y+70& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 7&=70 &(\text{Subtract }   2y \text{ from both sides})\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-7x-10-15x=-22x+83$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-7x-10-15x&=-22x+83\\\\ -22x-10&=-22x+83& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ -10&=83 &(\text{Add } 22x \text{ to both sides})\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $60z+50-97z=-37z+49$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. ###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}60z+50-97z&=-37z+49\\\\ -37z+50&=-37z+49& (\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 50&=49 &(\text{Add }37z \text{ to both sides})\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-17(y-2)=-17y+64$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.     [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-17(y-2)&=-17y+64\\\\ -17y+34&=-17y+64&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ 34&=64 &(\text{Add }  17y \text{ to both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-9(x+6)=-9x+108$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-9(x+6)&=-9x+108\\\\ -9x-54&=-9x+108&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ -54&=108 &(\text{Add }  9x \text{ to both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $14(z+3)=14z+21$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $z=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}14(z+3)&=14z+21\\\\ 14z+42&=14z+21&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ 42&=21 &(\text{Subtract }  14z \text{ from both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $4(y-30)=4y+12$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.     [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}4(y-30)&=4y+12\\\\ 4y-120&=4y+12&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ -120&=12 &(\text{Subtract }  4y \text{ from both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $7(y-8)=7y+42$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $y$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $y=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.     [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}7(y-8)&=7y+42\\\\ 7y-56&=7y+42&(\text{Distribute})\\\\ -56&=42 &(\text{Subtract }  7y \text{ from both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has no solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation  have ?**  $-4x-7+10x=-7+6x$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $x$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $x=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.      [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-4x-7+10x&=-7+6x\\\\ 6x-7&=-7+6x &(\text{Combine like terms})\\\\  -7&=-7&(\text{Subtract } 6x \text{ from both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has infinitely many solutions.

###The answer  The given equation has infinitely many solutions.

###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}3(y+41) &=3y+123\\\\ 3y+123&=3y+123&(\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 123&=123 &(\text{Subtract }  3y \text{ from both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has infinitely many solutions.

question.content: **How many solutions does the following equation have?**  $-14(z-5)=-14z+70$

hints.content: ###The strategy  Let's manipulate the equation in order to simplify it and isolate $z$. We should end with one of the following cases:  - An equation of the form $z=a$ (where $a$ is any number). In this case, the equation has exactly one solution.   - An equation of the form $a=a$ (where $a$ is a number). In this case, the equation has infinite solutions.    - An equation of the form $a=b$ (where $a$ and $b$ are different numbers). In this case, the equation has no solutions.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Simplifying the equation  $\begin{align}-14(z-5) &=-14z+70\\\\ -14z+70&=-14z+70&(\text{Combine like terms})\\\\ 70&=70 &(\text{Add }  14z \text{ to both sides})\\\\\end{align}$
###The answer  The given equation has infinitely many solutions.
